comments.comment_text: @17:50 about on press vs on release --  I think both are correct in different scenarios. I agree exactly that when you're mouse clicking in a UI on a button, you should be able to drag off before releasing to cancel. But if you're using a key press to do an attack in a game, then it 100% should be "on press" not "on release" (I'm aware some games actually make this a user option for quick-casting where "while you hold it" it shows you an aiming indicator, and that's fine too, as long as it's optional especially) -- but in general, like jumping or sliding in a game should be something that happens on press, as it makes the game feel snappier to the user's input.

comments.comment_text:
While this was certainly useful as far as showing an overview of the motivation of making the game and some critical techniques behind implementing core systems of the game itself, it doesn't get to what _programmers_ would consider the "hard" part and why so many "one-man team" games often don't get past proof-of-concept or to a point of enjoyability - designing the actual gameplay experience (final/non-placeholder graphics and other assets, levels, etc).

Around 2011 or 2012 I made a tech demo for a vertical scrolling shoot-em-up (aka "vertical shmup;" think games like Raiden, Ikaruga, 19XX, or the Touhou series) using JavaScript and the Sphere Engine. I was so focused on getting the underlying systems to work that I paid no attention to making an experience that would be _fun_ or _enjoyable._ I didn't prototype any proper enemy layouts, weapon loadouts, bullet sprays to navigate (for those who like those sorts of bullet-hell games), things like that. Over time, I learned that things like that should still be present in spec and focus even if the immediate task is not necessarily directly relevant. While I consider myself artistically inclined, I simply didn't put in the effort needed to make more than one player ship, one test enemy ship, a smattering of particle graphics, and some placeholder backgrounds and text graphics.

Mark Brown at Game Maker's Toolkit has an ongoing series of videos describing the making of his indie game "Mind Over Magnet" where he goes over not just the process of making and troubleshooting the systems, but also making and troubleshooting the levels, assets, and even the processes themselves. Even if one might not agree 100% with his specific philosophy or praxis (he _is_ using a Unity-based workflow, after all), he has shown himself to be a guy who puts his money where his mouth is in his dev efforts after building his channel making videos for years analyzing what makes games tick.

comments.comment_text:
The predictive movement / smoothing is actually very very easy. Both server and client communicate via a recursive signal which means that you can use audio engineering to control those. A highpass filter introduces a ring which will be your predictive positioning and a lowpass will smooth out the movement. Ideally, the 4 variables you are left with is the 2 cutoff frequencies and the 2 slopes which you can calibrate to the latency the user has at any given time. Sometimes you end up with a single-liner.

If you can't be bothered, just lowpass it. That also works and it is definitely a single liner.

It did work wonders with a physics engine running at 10hz I was playing with 'bout 10 years ago.

comments.comment_text:
act on press vs act on release
. Act on press is there for immediate response in situations where you don't need to change your mind about the action taken. Act on release is for exploratory actions where you aren't sure if the action you will be taking will fulfill the desired effect.
are you using a crossbow or a bow. with a crossbow you are already prepped to fire a certain bolt type and the only decision necessary is to select the location to fire. With a bow you need to hold the arrow armed and then release when ready, you can also change out the arrow without firing the one which is loaded.
They both have their place and need to be considered.
but... act on release can add in more bugs and edge cases than act on press.

The explanation at 34:36 is actually mind-blowingly helpful as I'm currently in the early stages of developing a game myself. I planned to implement an enemy that had motion kind of similar to a "Snatcher" or "Angry Trapper" from the jungle biome in Terraria, where its motion has a random wobbling component. comments.comment_text:
Making a multiplayer game that runs smoothly on the client while having the server maintain state is tremendously difficult. The client side needs to be responsive in an FPS.

It's generally done by having things like player movement being done on both the server and client. If there's a difference, defer to the server. It's really difficult to account for things like network lag and where the player should be at any point in time. If Player A presses fire, yet the communication to the sever takes 100 ms, what did he hit?

A must is to totally remove jittering movement even when the client and server are off by a bit.

The problem is difficult. Good interview question for somebody who has made this type of game though.

Valve has a good writeup on it for Counterstrike.

The only reason for me not use buffers is when the data is too big it's actually better fragmented otherwise it can't fit anywhere and it runs into sort of a SEGFAULT adjacent problem.

comments.comment_text: 28:12 Not exactly but pretty close. You want to think about the server the entire time, yes, but not necessarily server first. What matters is your architecture. You need to identify what might need to be shared, what stays on the client, what stays on the server, what is in both but not synced, etc. Converting a single player game to multiplayer is insanely hard because no one thought about responsabilities and state. If you remember the entire way through that this is a multiplayer game, nothing stops you from making your first prototype single player and doing the server later. What matters is that when it comes to networking, your state is already ready to be networked, and your gameplay logic isn't tangled up.

comments.comment_text: During my studies I made several projects, including a game, two of which were for commercial use. When I graduated from university, I submitted about 1000 resumes in half a year, and these were absolutely all open vacancies in the IT field in my region, i.e. not only vacancies for programmers, but also near-programmers, security specialists, etc. Out of a thousand resumes, I received about 5 interviews, two of them continued with tasks to solve, at the end of one of the tasks they told me that I was suitable, but they were waiting for the head of the department, then they would invite me to an interview with him, etc. and another time they supposedly hired me and the next day my employment was supposed to begin, but suddenly they wrote that they found someone else. Then for several more months I did nothing and slept all day long, since I could not find any work at all, and the money I earned on two commercial projects was already running out. I was desperate. In the end, after three interviews, one company hired me as a loader in a warehouse! A few months later, one of my friends hired me as a programmer in his department without any interviews. I worked there all the time until I left Russia. P.S. The hardest thing about being an ordinary programmer is to keep learning something new while your job is to move boxes or do something that is not related to learning something new in programming. Most of us never get a chance in this field, and doing this only for yourself all your life is very difficult or almost impossible.

In fact, I fail to see what kind of project there even exists that could not be turned into a fucking rocket ship project.
- Did you analyze competing TODO apps?
- Did you find the leading one and how did you decide to surpass it?
- Did you notice any lack of features common to all TODO apps?
- How did you do persistence and why?
- Did you create a TODO app that is SaaS or personal? Why?
- If it's SasS what auth did you use?
- Have you considered implementing analytics that would tell the person how long he took to complete the tasks?
- Have you implemented visualizations of those analytical insights and how would you do it?
- Have you implemented features that would help prioritize the tasks? Custom labels for priorities?
- Have you implemented notifications and how flexible is configuration of the notifications?

... it's just endless. Imagine creating Obsidian / Notion from your TODO app?
comments.author: @mindasb
